properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory For The Town Of Ituna

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Stuartburn
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-19T16:30:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-18T15:20:27-06:00, EAFB9C7B-DD9C-87D8-3EB4-DA7DF0BCF381
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant wintry weather is expected. Locations: central, western and southwestern Newfoundland. Time Span: Thursday morning to Friday afternoon. Remarks: A developing storm is forecast to bring wintry weather to the island later this week. While it is too soon to provide specific details, the potential exists for a prolonged wet, heavy snowfall event with gusty northeasterly winds. The snow will likely be heaviest inland with significant accumulations possible. Over coastal areas, precipitation is expected to occur as a mixture of snow and rain. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-19T11:12:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-18T19:13:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3803162493.2019
Area: Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. A prolonged period of freezing rain is expected to begin overnight tonight and persist into Tuesday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-19T06:42:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-18T14:43:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0415401518.2019
Area: Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Time span: Tuesday morning until Wednesday morning. Locations: Northern Peninsula East as well as Port Saunders and the Straits. Remarks: Snow will begin on the Northern Peninsula Tuesday morning then ease briefly near midnight Tuesday night before a second, less extensive, round of snow begins overnight. The snow will then taper off Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-19T06:22:31-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

The freezing rain should change to snow Tuesday morning ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant period of freezing rain expected. Freezing rain amounts: 5 to 15 mm. Locations: Green Bay - White Bay, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Buchans and the interior, the Burgeo highway, and inland areas of the west coast from Gros Morne National Park to Channel-Port aux Basques. Time span: late overnight tonight through Tuesday morning. Remarks: Freezing rain is expected to begin overnight over inland areas of southwestern Newfoundland including the Burgeo Highway, then spread northward Tuesday morning, potentially lasting for several hours in some areas. The freezing rain will change to rain by noon Tuesday over all areas except through Green Bay - White Bay where it will become a mix of rain and snow. Areas near White Bay could see up to 10 cm of snow Tuesday afternoon. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-19T11:11:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-18T19:12:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0482167581.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system moving into Alberta tonight will bring snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 centimetres for parts of the province on Tuesday. Snow will begin later tonight in southwestern Alberta, and will track eastward early Tuesday morning. Snow will taper off by Wednesday morning as the system moves through Saskatchewan. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-19T14:30:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-18T22:31:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3765229844.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Time span: Tuesday morning until Wednesday morning. Locations: Northern Peninsula East as well as Port Saunders and the Straits. Remarks: Snow will begin on the Northern Peninsula Tuesday morning then ease briefly near midnight Tuesday night before a second, less extensive, round of snow begins overnight. The snow will then taper off Wednesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong easterly winds gusting up to 100 km/h are expected to develop this evening and persist overnight, diminishing on Tuesday morning. ### Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
